Average Pooling Layer

Like Convolution(), AveragePooling() processes items arranged on an N-dimensional grid, such as an image. Typically, each item is a vector. For each item, average-pooling computes the element-wise mean over a window (“receptive field”) of items surrounding the item’s position on the grid.

AveragePooling(filter_shape, strides = 1, pad = FALSE, name = "")

Arguments

filter_shape

(int or tuple of ints) – shape (spatial extent) of the receptive field, not including the input feature-map depth. E.g. (3,3) for a 2D convolution.
strides

(int or tuple of ints, defaults to 1) – stride (increment when sliding over the input). Use a tuple to specify a per-axis value.
pad

(bool or tuple of bools, defaults to False) – if False, then the pooling #' operation will be shifted over the “valid” area of input, that is, no value #' outside the area is used. If pad=True on the other hand, pooling will be #' applied to all input positions, and positions outside the valid region will #' be excluded from the averaging. Use a tuple to specify a per-axis value.
name

(str, defaults to '') – the name of the function instance in the network

Value

A function that accepts one argument and applies the average-pooling operation to it

Details

The size (spatial extent) of the receptive field is given by filter <- shape. E.g. for 2D pooling, filter <- shape should be a tuple of two integers, such as (5,5).

Examples

f <- avg_pooling(c(3, 3), strides = 2)
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): could not find function "avg_pooling"
h <- ops_input_variable(c(num_classes))
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): could not find function "ops_input_variable"
